body.p: This document describes how developers and contributors should write code to be included into the main CIlib tree. The reasoning behind these conventions is mainly for consistency, readability and maintainability.

section.name: General code style and convention
section.p: All working files within the source tree of CIlib must adhere to the following conventions:

ul.li: License Header: All source files will add the GPLv2 license header. NOTE: CIlib will not compile if the check for header information fails.
Trailing whitespaces: All trailing whitespaces must be removed.
Netbeans users should use the "Remove Trailing Whitespace" option under the "Source" menu item.
Eclipse users can use the Anyedit Eclipse Plugin to automatically remove trailing whitespace.

section.p: Style conventions applying to the project:

ul.li: Indentation: No tabs are allowed for indentation! Use spaces.
Line wrapping: A column-width of 120 is to be used.

section.name: Java code
section.p: All classes are to be written following the JavaBeans Specification, barring a special reason. Such reasons include the class being a Singleton or Helper class that is not required during the XML to Java binding process.
The CIlib stype for Java source files is generally accepted to be:

ul.li: All class members are to be given names in CamelCaps (which is the accepted Java style).
